facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 4, 1962 of Kerala High Court in Writ Appeal No. 17 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 4, 1962 of the Kerala High Court, Ernakulam, in Writ Appeal No. 17 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant holds license for supply of electrical energy in Ernakulam and other places in Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the holder of a license for the supply of electrical energy in Ernakulam and other places in Cochin.

facts.text: License originally granted to managing agents under Cochin Electricity Regulation III of 1902, assigned to appellant with permission.

anchor.surface_text: The license was originally granted to the managing agents of the appellant under the Cochin Electricity Regulation III of 1902 then in force in Cochin and subsequently assigned to the appellant with the permission of the Cochin Government.

facts.text: License commencement date is December 3, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The date of the commencement of the license is December 3, 1935.

facts.text: 25-year period in license expired on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The period of 25 years mentioned in cl. 15(a) of the license expired on December 2, 1960.

facts.text: Kerala Electricity Board constituted on March 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1957 the Kerala Electricity Board was constituted,

facts.text: State Electricity Board served notice Ex. B on February 11, 1959, electing to purchase on expiry of December 2, 1960, but invalid as not in accordance with s.7(4).

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1959, the State Electricity Board served on the appellant a notice, Ex. B, of its election to purchase the undertaking of, the appellant on the expiry of December 2, 1960, but this notice was not being in accordance with s. 7(4) was of no legal effect.

facts.text: Indian Electricity Amendment Act, 1959 (Act 32 of 1959) substituted s.6 effective September 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: By the Indian Electricity (Amendment) Act, 1959 (Act 32 of 1959), s.6 now in force was substituted for the old s.7 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910, with effect from September 5, 1959.

facts.text: State Electricity Board served notice Ex. D on October 24, 1959, electing to purchase on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On October 24, 1959, the State Electricity Board served upon the appellant a notice Ex. D, of its election to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December 2, 1960.

facts.text: State Electricity Board served notice Ex. E on October 29, 1959, electing to purchase.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1959, the State Electricity Board served upon the appellant another notice, Ex. E, of its election.

facts.text: State Government served notice Ex. G on November 20, 1959, electing to purchase on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1959, the State Government served upon the appellant a notice, Ex. G, of its election to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December 2, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition on November 14, 1960 in Kerala High Court against State and Board re notices B,D,E,G.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1960, the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court of Kerala impleading the State of Kerala and the Kerala State Electricity Board and asking for the issue of appropriate writs and orders restraining them from taking any action pursuant to the notices, Exs. B,D,E and G.

facts.text: On December 20, 1961, single Judge of Kerala HC ordered notices B,D,E ignored, upheld Ex. G, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: On December 20, 1961, a learned single Judge of the High Court passed the following order... the writ petition has to be dismissed.

facts.text: Division Bench of Kerala HC dismissed writ appeal on October 4, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated October 4, 1962, a Division Bench of the High Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: State Electricity Board waived rights under notices B, D, E.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this order was that the State Electricity Board waived and abandoned all its rights of purchase of the undertaking under the notices, Exs. B, D and E,

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal under certificate by High Court under Arts. 133(1)(a) and 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant now appeals to this Court under a certificate granted by the High Court under Arts. 133(1)(a) and 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

facts.text: Clause 15(a) of license: option exercisable after 25 years from commencement, then every 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 15(a) of the license held by the appellant provides: The option of purchase given by Section 7, sub-section (1) of the Regulation shall first be exercisable on the expiration of 25 years from the commencement of this license and on the expiration of every subsequent period of ten years during the continuance of this license.

facts.text: Last date for two years' notice under old s.7(4) was December 2, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for giving the two years' notice of the election to purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960 required under s. 7(4) of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 expired on December 2, 1958.

facts.text: State Electricity Board abandoned and waived its option of purchase.

anchor.surface_text: As far as the State Electricity Board is concerned, it has abandoned and waived its option of purchase on the expiry of 25 years.

facts.text: Supreme Court held State Government has no option under s.6(2) as Board elected to purchase.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth contention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound... the State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and restrained State from acting on Ex. G.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the notice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959.

facts.text: Indian Electricity Act, 1910 made applicable to Travancore-Cochin by Part-B States Laws Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On the merger of Travancore-Cochin with the Union of India, the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 was made applicable by the Part-B States Laws Act, 1951 (Act III of 1951) to the Travancore-Cochin area, and the Cochin Electricity Regulation stood repealed.

facts.text: Electricity Supply Act, 1948 made applicable to Travancore-Cochin by Part-B States Laws Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Electricity Supply Act, 1948 (Act 54 of 1948) was also made applicable to the Travancore-Cochin area by the Part-B States Laws Act, 1951.

facts.text: By s.71 of Act 54 of 1948, purchase rights vested in Kerala Electricity Board.

anchor.surface_text: and by s.71 of Act 54 of 1948, any right and option to purchase the undertaking of the licensee under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 was transferred to and vested in the Board.

facts.text: State Electricity Board did not send intimation to State Government 18 months before expiry as required by s.6(4), but excused as impossible.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 came into force on September 5, 1959, and the relevant period expired on December 2, 1960. In the circumstances, the giving of the requisite notice of 18 months... was impossible...
s. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

issues.text: whether the proposed acquisition of the electrical supply undertaking of the appellant by the State of Kerala in pursuance of the notice Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959 is authorised by s. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910

anchor.surface_text: The short question in this appeal is whether the proposed acquisition of the electrical supply undertaking of the appellant by the State of Kerala in pursuance of the notice Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959 is authorised by s. 6

issues.text: whether the failure to serve two years' notice under old s.7(4) conferred a vested right on the appellant to hold the license until December 2, 1970, not taken away by new s.6

anchor.surface_text: as the two years notice in writing of the election to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December, 2, 1960 was not served on the appellant as required by the old s. 7(4) of the Indian Electricity Act. 1910

issues.text: whether the expression 'on the expiration of each such period as is specified in the license' in new s.6(1)(a) means only a period on the expiry of which the option may be legally exercised under old law

anchor.surface_text: the expression on the expiration of each such period as is specified in the license in the new s.6(1)(a) means a period which has not expired and on the expiry of which the option may be legally exercised

issues.text: whether sub-sections (4) and (5) of new s.6 require the relevant period to expire at least 18 months after the coming into force of new s.6

anchor.surface_text: sub-sections (4) and (5) of the new s.6 show that the period on the expiry of which the option under sub-s(1) of s.6 is exercisable, is a period which would expire at least 18 months after the coming into force

issues.text: whether the State Government acquired no option under s.6(2) since the State Electricity Board duly elected to purchase

anchor.surface_text: in any event, the State Electricity Board having duly elected to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December 2, 1960, the State Government acquired no option of purchase under sub-s(2) of s.6

issues.text: whether absence of two years' notice under old s.7(4) conferred vested right or immunity taken away by new s.6 requiring only one year's notice

anchor.surface_text: that the absence of two years notice under the old s.7(4) of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 did not confer upon the appellant a vested right to hold the license until the expiry of December 2, 1970

issues.text: whether any vested right under old s.7 was taken away by new s.6 expressly applying to prior licenses, with 25-year period as specified

anchor.surface_text: assuming that the appellant acquired under the old s.7 a vested right to hold the license until December 2, 1970, such vested right was taken away by the new s.6, which expressly applies to licenses granted before its commencement

issues.text: whether sub-sections (4) and (5) of new s.6 cut down the plain meaning of sub-s(1), allowing option on expiry of 25 years despite less than 18 months remaining

anchor.surface_text: sub-sections (4) and (5) of the new s.6 did not cut down the plain meaning of sub-s(1) of the section and the option on the expiry of the period of 25 years was vested under sub-s(1) of s.6

issues.text: whether State Electricity Board deemed not to have elected due to no 18-month intimation under s.6(4), vesting option in State Government under s.6(2)

anchor.surface_text: as the State Electricity Board did not send to the State Government any intimation in writing of its intention to exercise the option on the expiry of December 2, 1960 as required by sub-s(4) of s.6, the Board must be deemed to have elected not to exercise this option

issues.text: whether the 18-month intimation requirement under s.6(4) applies where compliance is impossible after commencement of s.6, excusing performance per maxim lex non cogitat ad impossibilia

anchor.surface_text: the performance of this impossible duty must be excused in accordance with the maxim, lex non cogitat ad impossibilia (the law does not compel the doing of impossibilities), and sub-s(4) of s.6 must be construed as not being applicable

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth companytention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired numberright or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

arguments.claim: the State Electricity Board was not required to give the notice under sub-s(4) of s.6 in respect of its option of purchase on the expiry of 25 years. It must follow that the Board cannot be deemed to have elected not to purchase the undertaking under sub-s(4) of s.6. By the notice served upon the appellant, the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of 25 years.

arguments.court_reasoning: As far as the State Electricity Board is concerned, it has abandoned and waived its option of purchase on the expiry of 25 years.

holdings.text: The State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6 because the option vested in the State Electricity Board under s.6(1) and the Board duly elected to purchase.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth contention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(1) vests primary option in Board; Board's election under notices to licensee prevents vesting in State under s.6(2); assumes arguendo option available after 25 years.

holdings.text: The 18-month intimation requirement under s.6(4) does not apply where compliance is impossible after commencement of s.6, excused per maxim lex non cogitat ad impossibilia.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 came into force on September 5, 1959, and the relevant period expired on December 3. 1960. In the circumstances, the giving of the requisite notice of 18 months in respect of the option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960, was impossible from the very commencement of s.6. The performance of this impossible duty must be excused in accordance with the maxim, lex non cogitat ad impossibilia (the law does not compel the doing of impossibilities), and sub-s 4  of s.6 must be construed as not being applicable to a case where compliance with it is impossible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 effective Sep 1959, only 15 months to expiry Dec 1960 makes 18-month notice impossible; law does not compel impossibilities, so provision inapplicable.

holdings.text: State Electricity Board duly elected to purchase by notice served on licensee; not deemed to have elected not to purchase under s.6(4).

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore, hold that the State Electricity Board was not required to give the notice under sub-s 4  of s.6 in respect of its option of purchase on the expiry of 25 years. It must follow that the Board cannot be deemed to have elected not to purchase the undertaking under sub-s 4  of s.6. By the notice served upon the appellant, the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of 25 years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No s.6(4) notice required due to impossibility; direct notice to licensee under s.6(1) suffices for election.

holdings.text: Notice Ex. B served by Board on Feb 11, 1959 invalid as not in accordance with old s.7(4).

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1959, the State Electricity Board served on the appellant a notice, Ex. B, of its election to purchase the undertaking of, the appellant on the expiry of December 2, 1960, but this notice was not being in accordance with s. 7(4) was of no legal effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Old s.7(4) required 2 years' notice before Dec 2 1960 expiry; served after deadline of Dec 2 1958.

holdings.text: State Electricity Board waived and abandoned rights under notices Exs. B, D, E.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this order was that the State Electricity Board waived and abandoned all its rights of purchase of the undertaking under the notices, Exs. B, D and E,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on High Court single judge order and Board's representation; accepted by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; State of Kerala restrained from acting under notice Ex. G.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the notice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from invalidity of State's option under s.6.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth contention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 came into force on September 5, 1959, and the relevant period expired on December 3. 1960. In the circumstances, the giving of the requisite notice of 18 months in respect of the option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960, was impossible from the very commencement of s.6. The performance of this impossible duty must be excused in accordance with the maxim, lex non cogitat ad impossibilia (the law does not compel the doing of impossibilities), and sub-s 4  of s.6 must be construed as not being applicable to a case where compliance with it is impossible.

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore, hold that the State Electricity Board was not required to give the notice under sub-s 4  of s.6 in respect of its option of purchase on the expiry of 25 years. It must follow that the Board cannot be deemed to have elected not to purchase the undertaking under sub-s 4  of s.6. By the notice served upon the appellant, the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of 25 years.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the numberice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959. The respondent
